elements.title: Fair Value and Carrying Value Comparison

data.value: As of December 31, 2022, fair value was $908,000 with a carrying value of $572,153.
Fair value increased by $134,000 (17.3%) but carrying value slightly decreased by $4,153 (0.7%).
Weighted average capitalization rate increased from 3.30% at the end of 2021 to 3.47% at the end of 2022.
Rate increases result in negative impacts (up to -$63,000), while decreases show positive impacts (up to $65,000).
Negative impacts can reach -$115,000 with decreases up to $146,000.
The relationship shows a significant negative impact of up to -$160,000 for increases and positive up to $243,000 for decreases.

elements.title: Auditor’s Responsibilities and Management’s Responsibilities for Financial Statements

data.value: Preparation and fair presentation of consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS.
Obtain reasonable assurance that the consolidated financial statements are free from material misstatement.
Management is responsible for assessing the Trust’s ability to continue as a going concern.
Considered material if it could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users.
Management is responsible for internal control necessary for fair presentation.
Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial statements, including the disclosures.
Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or business activities.
Responsibility for direction, supervision and performance of the group audit.
Communicate with those charged with governance regarding planned scope, timing, and significant audit findings.
Provide a statement on compliance with relevant ethical requirements regarding independence.
Determine matters of most significance in the audit of the consolidated financial statements.
Donald M. Flinn

elements.title: Fair Value and Carrying Value Comparison

data.value: The table compares fair value and carrying value of assets or liabilities for two reporting periods. As of December 31, 2022, the fair value was $5,050,000 with a carrying value of $3,936,427, while on December 31, 2021, the fair value was $5,026,000 with a carrying value of $3,875,442. There is a consistent pattern where fair values exceed carrying values by approximately $1.1 million across both periods, with slight increases in both metrics from 2021 to 2022.

data.key: Accrued straight-line rent receivable on December 31, 2022
Accrued straight-line rent receivable on December 31, 2021

data.value: This table presents a breakdown of property-related assets and their carrying values for two periods. The total carrying value increased from 3,875,442 in 2021 to 3,936,427 in 2022, primarily driven by growth in income properties. Income properties represent the largest component, accounting for approximately 89% of the total carrying value in 2022.

data.key: Weighted average capitalization rate on December 31, 2022
Weighted average capitalization rate on December 31, 2021

data.value: The table shows the weighted average capitalization rate for two periods. There was an increase in the rate from 5.65% at the end of 2021 to 5.94% at the end of 2022, representing a 29 basis points increase year-over-year. This suggests a slight increase in the required rate of return or potentially higher risk assessment during this period.

This table shows the sensitivity analysis of capitalization rates, demonstrating the impact of rate changes on values. For a 0.25% change, an increase results in a $203,000 decrease while a decrease leads to a $222,000 increase. The impact becomes more pronounced with larger rate changes, with a 0.75% rate change causing a $560,000 decrease on increase and a $735,000 increase on decrease. The relationship appears to be non-linear, with larger rate changes having proportionally greater impacts on values.

The table shows property transactions throughout 2022, including both acquisitions and dispositions. Early in the year (January-May), there were mostly acquisitions, particularly from Related Parties, with significant transactions including a 235,000 sq ft property for $38,050 and a 183,000 sq ft property for $34,035. Later in the year (June-November), the pattern shifted to primarily dispositions to Third Parties, with the largest disposition being 191,000 sq ft for $26,331 in November. The total square footage acquired was approximately 589,000 sq ft, while total dispositions were approximately 401,000 sq ft. The transactions involved Related Parties, Third Parties, and one Joint Venture partner.

Doing what’s right is at the foundation of everything we do. Being responsible, accountable, transparent, and honest is part of who we are and what we accomplish.
We pride ourselves on our commitment to create positive and sustainable impact for our clients, partners, team members, and the environment.
We lead with empathy and strive to truly understand each other in a way that maximizes collaboration, quality, and high performance.
Everyone is encouraged to bring their unique and authentic self to work.
We are proud of the results we achieve, honour our learnings, and continually raise the bar.
We build and operate spaces of which people want to be part.
We think long term.
We make communities even better.
We live our values.

Despite the challenges that come our way, our team can always rely on each other to rise above them. I’m privileged to work with a group of compassionate, supportive, hard-working people who are driven to succeed, lead with integrity, and are prepared for a sustainable future.
Karen Charlton

Crombie’s commitment to collaboration and inclusive decision-making empowers me to think carefully about our future, bring my best ideas forward, and deliver to my greatest ability. We are a highly experienced and supportive team, dedicated to delivering excellence together through shared objectives that support Crombie’s long-term vision.
Kevin Clark

Crombie has made significant strides to formalize a sustainability program that is built on trustworthy data and ethical science. In my role, I have the privilege of working with teammates of varying functions across the business and I’m proud to be a part of an organization where sustainable practices are prioritized in all levels of decision-making.
Adam Cochrane

My role allows me to work alongside all areas of the business, with the goal to help others improve in their processes and efficiencies. This requires a high level of collaboration and a collective commitment to Crombie’s guiding values.
Campbell DeMont

Working collaboratively across the organization allows me to achieve my focus of providing the highest level of service to our tenants. I know that my ideas are heard and respected, and I’m valued for the work that I do.
Monika Heric

Management makes judgments, estimates, and assumptions that affect the financial reporting of assets and liabilities, income, and expenses. Significant areas include impairment, employee benefits, investment properties, etc.
Assets and liabilities in financial statements require fair value measurement, which is based on observable market data or discounted cash flows.
Acquisitions are assessed to determine if they are business combinations or asset acquisitions.
Investment properties are valued based on appraisals by independent companies over a maximum period of four years.

elements.title: Change in other non-cash operating items

data.key: Prepaid expenses and deposits and other assets

data.value:
This table presents a comprehensive property portfolio listing, primarily consisting of retail properties across various Canadian locations. The portfolio includes retail plazas and freestanding retail properties with varying ownership percentages (ranging from 1% to 100%) and Gross Leasable Area (GLA). Notable observations include:

1. Most properties maintain high occupancy rates, with many at 100%
2. Property types are predominantly retail (both plaza and freestanding)
3. Geographic distribution spans multiple provinces, with significant presence in British Columbia
4. Total portfolio GLA (excluding Joint Ventures) is approximately 18,445,000 square feet
5. Overall portfolio occupancy rate is 96.9%
6. Includes some joint venture properties at the bottom of the listing with 50% ownership structures.
Approximately 18,445,000
High occupancy rates across the portfolio, most properties are 95-100% committed.
Future Investment Potential
VECTOM: 34.1%, Major Markets: 25.3%, Rest of Canada: 40.6%
Healthy NOI growth as part of the overall portfolio performance.
96.9% occupancy across 289 active investment properties.
Weighted average lease term remains stable.
Details on renewal leasing spread indicate strong activity.

This table shows distributions to unitholders and related metrics comparing 2022 to 2021. Total distributions increased from $144,559 to $157,840 year-to-date, representing a positive variance of $13,281. Both FFO and AFFO payout ratios showed improvement in 2022, with FFO payout ratio decreasing from 78.1% to 77.5% (YTD) and AFFO payout ratio improving from 91.8% to 89.0% (YTD).

elements.title: Non-GAAP Financial Measures Descriptions and Reconciliations

data.value: Property NOI on a cash basis

Property NOI on a cash basis, which excludes non-cash straight-line rent recognition and non-cash tenant incentive amortization. Management believes that Property NOI on a cash basis is an important measure of operating performance as it reflects the cash generated by the properties period-over-period.
Same-asset Property Cash NOI starting on page 44
Same-asset property cash NOI

Same-asset properties are properties owned and operated by Crombie throughout the current and comparative reporting periods, excluding any property that was designated for redevelopment, or was subject to disposition, during either the current or comparative period. Same-asset property cash NOI includes Crombie's proportionate ownership of jointly operated properties but currently excludes properties owned in joint ventures. The number of same-asset properties was 274 as at December 31, 2022.
Same-asset Property Cash NOI starting on page 44
Funds from operations (FFO)

Crombie follows the recommendations of REALPAC's January 2022 guidance in calculating FFO, and defines FFO as increase (decrease) in net assets attributable to Unitholders, adjusted for: gain or loss on disposal of investment properties, gain on distribution from equity-accounted investments, impairment charges, depreciation and amortization expense, adjustments for equity-accounted entities, operational expenses from right-of-use assets, incremental internal leasing expenses, finance costs distributions, and change in fair value of financial instruments.
Funds from Operations (FFO)* starting on page 46
FFO payout ratio
FFO payout ratio shows the proportion of FFO paid to Unitholders in the form of distributions
Funds from

elements.title: Non-GAAP Financial Measures Description and Reconciliation

data.value: Crombie considers AFFO to be a useful measure in evaluating the recurring economic performance of its operating results which will be used to support future distribution payments. Crombie follows the recommendations of REALPAC's January 2022 guidance in calculating AFFO. AFFO reflects earnings after adjustments in arriving at FFO and various other financial metrics. Management believes this is a useful measure in comparing period-over-period operating results.

AFFO payout ratio shows the proportion of AFFO paid to Unitholders in the form of distributions for the period, expressed as a percentage of AFFO. Calculated by dividing finance costs — distributions to Unitholders by AFFO for the period. Used in evaluating distribution payment sustainability.

data.key: investment properties as a % of unsecured debt
data.value: Properties not pledged as security for debt obligations. Used to assess unencumbered investment properties available for secured financing to satisfy unsecured debt obligations.
Used to evaluate Crombie's flexibility to incur additional financial leverage.

Represents debt excluding transaction costs, including Crombie's share of debt in equity-accounted joint ventures. Used in calculating debt to gross fair value and debt to trailing 12 months adjusted EBITDA.

data.key: Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization ("adjusted EBITDA")
data.value: Represents earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization with certain adjustments. Used in debt metrics and assessing ability to service debt, fund capital projects, and acquire properties.
Used to assess Crombie’s financial leverage, to measure its ability to meet financial obligations and measure its balance sheet strength.

Represents finance costs from operations, excluding amortization of deferred financing costs. It includes Crombie’s share of interest from equity-accounted joint ventures. Adjusted interest expense is used in the calculation of our interest service coverage and debt service coverage ratios.
These ratios are useful in determining Crombie’s ability to service the interest requirements of its outstanding debt.
These ratios are useful in determining Crombie’s ability to service the interest requirements of its outstanding debt.

elements.title: MANAGEMENT’S STATEMENT OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR FINANCIAL REPORTING

data.value: The management of Crombie Real Estate Investment Trust is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the accompanying annual consolidated financial statements and MD&A.
Prepared in accordance with International Accounting Standards (IFRS).
Management has established internal controls to ensure reliability of financial records and authorized transactions.
As of December 31, 2022, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer evaluated the internal controls over financial reporting as appropriately designed and effective.
The Audit Committee oversees management’s responsibility for financial reporting and meets regularly with management and the independent auditor.
Donald E. Clow, President and Chief Executive Officer; Clinton D. Keay, Chief Financial Officer and Secretary.
February 22, 2023

The accompanying consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Crombie Real Estate Investment Trust and its subsidiaries as at December 31, 2022 and 2021.
Conducted in accordance with Canadian generally accepted auditing standards.
Independent of the Trust in accordance with the ethical requirements relevant to the audit.

Consolidated balance sheets, consolidated statements of comprehensive income, consolidated statements of changes in net assets, consolidated statements of cash flows, and notes to the consolidated financial statements.

data.value: Crombie has a single reportable segment.
Crombie owns and operates primarily retail, retail-related industrial, office, and mixed-use real estate assets located in Canada.
Crombie has agreed to indemnify its trustees and officers, and particular employees, in accordance with Crombie’s policies.
Crombie maintains insurance policies that may provide coverage against certain claims.

elements.title: Crombie Financial Strength and Risk Management

data.value: Notable deleveraging, well-laddered debt maturities, and balanced near-term expiries.
Multiple sources of capital including equity issuance, unsecured notes, and bank credit facilities.
$200 million issuance in January 2022 at $17.45.
Disposed of eight investment properties for total gross proceeds of $176 million.
Commercial and residential.
BBB(low) with a stable trend.
Significant availability of liquidity.
Reduce total leverage over the medium/long-term
D/GFV* is 41.8% at December 31, 2022 compared to 45.3% at December 31, 2021.
Maintain minimum of $250 million liquidity
Increased liquidity to $583.0M, up $75.2M from 2021
Improve weighted average term to maturity
Decrease to 4.7 years at December 31, 2022 versus 5.1 years at December 31, 2021.
Lower cost of capital through equity raises and/or innovative funding solutions, such as capital recycling
During 2022, Crombie raised $200M of equity at a record price of $17.45 per Unit and completed dispositions for cash proceeds of $173.8M.
Maintain balance sheet strength during current period of rising interest rates
Reduce mortgage debt outstanding by $154M from December 31, 2021.
Increase unencumbered asset pool
Expanded unencumbered asset pool by approximately 23% to $2.2B since December 31, 2021.

elements.title: Management’s Discussion and Analysis on Development Risks

data.value: Crombie faces development risks associated with construction delays, cost overruns, and revenue projections.
Crombie's joint arrangements may limit control over property operations and expose to default risks by partners.
Valuation is based on capitalization rates influenced by net operating income; incorrect assumptions can affect fair value disclosures.
Empire holds a 41.5% interest in Crombie, which relies on Empire's retail operations for revenue.
Trustees may encounter conflicts due to interests in similar investments; provisions exist to manage these conflicts.
Crombie's reliance on key personnel presents a risk; there is no key person insurance in place.
Credit Risk
Credit risk arises from the possibility that tenants may experience financial difficulty and be unable to fulfill their lease commitments.
Crombie mitigates credit risk by geographical diversification, diversifying both its tenant mix and asset mix, and conducting credit assessments for new and renewing tenants.
Crombie’s largest tenant, Empire, represents 58.0% of AMR.
Crombie determines expected credit loss in accordance with IFRS 9’s simplified approach.
Liquidity risk is the risk that Crombie may not have access to sufficient debt and equity capital to fund its growth program.
Crombie seeks to mitigate liquidity risk using a disciplined approach to capital management.
BBB (low) with a Stable trend

elements.title: Risk Management and Interest Rate Risk

data.value: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks associated with an investment in Crombie’s securities.
Interest rate risk is the potential for financial loss arising from increases in interest rates.
Crombie mitigates risk by utilizing staggered debt maturities and limiting the use of permanent floating rate debt.
Canadian prime interest rates have increased significantly from 2.45% at December 31, 2021 to 6.70% effective January 25, 2023.

Crombie has a floating rate revolving credit facility available to a maximum of $400,000, an unsecured non-revolving credit facility with a balance of $150,000 outstanding, and other credit facilities with specified limits and outstanding balances.

data.value: A number of factors discussed under 'Risk Management' could cause actual results, performance, achievements, prospects, or opportunities to differ materially.
Readers should not place undue reliance on forward-looking statements.
Crombie assumes no obligation to update or revise forward-looking statements unless required by applicable securities legislation.

This document includes statements about our objectives, plans, goals, strategies, future growth, financial condition, results of operations, cash flows, performance, business prospects and opportunities.
These statements are forward-looking because they are based on management’s expectations about the future – they are not historical facts.

Forward-looking statements include statements regarding our development pipeline size, timing and costs, and statements containing words like anticipates, expects, believes, estimates, could, intends, may, plans, predicts, projects, will, would, foresees and other similar expressions, or the negative of these words.
For more information and a caution about using forward-looking information, see the Forward-Looking Information section in the MD&A on page 85.
Certain financial measures in this document, including FFO, AFFO, SANOI, debt to trailing 12 months adjusted EBITDA, and D/GFV, are not defined terms under GAAP.
They are not a reliable way to compare us to other companies.
See the Non-GAAP Financial Measures section in the MD&A on page 82.
Represents debt, including Crombie’s share of debt held in equity-accounted joint ventures, excluding transaction costs.

calculation of our debt to gross fair value and debt to trailing 12 months adjusted EBITDA. Represents earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization, excluding certain items such as amortization of tenant incentives, impairment of investment properties, gain (loss) on disposal of investment properties, and gain on distribution from equity-accounted investments. It includes Crombie's share of revenue, operating expenses, and general and administrative expenses from equity-accounted joint ventures. Adjusted EBITDA is a non-GAAP measure that is used as an input in several of our debt metrics.

Represents finance costs from operations, including Crombie's share of interest from equity-accounted joint ventures, excluding amortization of deferred financing costs. Adjusted interest expense is a non-GAAP measure that is used in the calculation of our interest service coverage and debt service coverage ratios.
Adjusted funds from operations. Crombie follows the recommendations of REALPAC's January 2022 guidance in determining AFFO.
Annual minimum rent. This represents annualized fixed minimum rent payable by the tenant pursuant to the terms of the lease.
Square footage. Represents assets that have not been pledged as security or collateral under a secured credit agreement or mortgage.
Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary, Toronto, Ottawa-Gatineau, Montreal, as defined by Statistics Canada 2021 boundaries for census metropolitan areas and census agglomeration.
Weighted average term to maturity.

A formal municipal rezoning application has been submitted for the purpose of achieving a new land use (i.e. residential, mixed-use) submitted and generally to obtain higher levels of density and building height.

Strategic
Empire
The partnership aims to enhance market reach and leverage synergies to bolster product offerings.
Resilient and growing portfolio
Effective and efficient property management; Strategic acquisitions/dispositions
Resilient grocery-anchored, needs-based properties that meet the needs of our tenants, their customers and communities; Stable and growing cash flow
Strategic partnership

Strategically engage with Empire to complete accretive investments such as conversions, modernizations, expansions, and e-commerce customer fulfillment centres and spoke facilities, as well as unlocking major developments
Intentionally curated portfolio designed to meet Empire and Crombie's current and future needs, including unlocking development opportunities
Development pipeline
Planning and zoning of land; Design and delivery of projects
High-quality real estate that enhances communities and provides sustainable long-term growth
Strong financial condition
Reasonable and balanced debt ladder; Multiple sources of capital and ample liquidity; Disciplined and innovative capital funding and management; Strong balance sheet
Optimized cost of capital; Available capital sources; Minimized financial risk
A highly skilled team

Attract, develop, and retain a talented team that is committed to advancing our purpose, values, and overall business strategy; Prioritize employee engagement, development, and community outreach; Focus on environmental, social, and governance footprint, including a sustainability strategy centered on creating value by developing our properties in a way that enhances local communities and protects our environment

Diverse and inclusive team of skilled real estate professionals; Experienced and focused leadership; Address the needs of our employees and care for our communities; Minimized environmental impact of our buildings and operations; Strong governance; Strong risk management and risk appetite framework; Supported communities
Crombie has always been guided by the value we place on community, which has helped shape and strengthen our sustainability commitments.
We continue to develop and operate our properties in a way that enhances urban and rural communities and protects the environment.
Taking a sustainable approach to our business is vital to the short-, medium-, and long-term health of our company.
We have embedded sustainability principles into the way we operate since inception.
We continued to advance our environmental, social and governance priorities in 2022.
The Board and senior leadership team believe climate change is a real issue.
Crombie leveraged an ESG software platform to conduct an inventory of GHG emissions.
$15.2 million invested in LED upgrades at 155 properties.
~2 million sq. ft. of BOMA BEST® certifications achieved.
31.3 metric tonnes of organic matter diverted from the landfill in 2022.
Avalon Mall received BOMA BEST® Gold certification and the 2022 BOMA NL Earth Award.
Continued to engage with tenants, suppliers, and other stakeholders.

elements.title: Social Impact and Corporate Governance at Crombie REIT

data.value: Our people enable our pathway to enrich sustainability at Crombie.
Crombie was selected as one of Atlantic Canada’s Top Employers and Nova Scotia’s Top Employers for 2022.
6,000+ hours volunteered by employees
42 community initiatives supported
30% of hires in the year were diverse candidates
66% of leadership development program participants are women
33% female trustees, 100% independent Board chair and committee chairs
Support for Bronte Market Square, including seating areas, water feature, and events for local residents.
Rooftop spaces with plants and flowers, urban beehives managed by Alvéole.
Team members prioritized community safety, supported the needs of properties during hurricanes.
Participated in inclusive communications training program in 2022.
Celebration of African Heritage Month and initiatives for inclusive language.

elements.title: Crombie REIT Annual Report 2022 - ESG Initiatives

data.value: Crombie has implemented processes and controls to mitigate cyber security risks, environmental risks, and climate change risks.
Crombie published its second annual Sustainability Report in Q2 2022.
Crombie updated its Sustainable Development Policy and introduced ESG risk assessments across its portfolio.
Crombie is not aware of any material non-compliance with environmental laws at its properties.
Crombie is evaluating recommendations from the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures.
